Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Hydra TRP Channels: Expression and Functional Analysis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
Transient receptor potential (TRP) channels are a superfamily of cation channels that regulate processes as diverse as olfaction, thermal perception, pain, synaptic transmission and development. They can be activated by both environmental stimuli (e.g. chemicals, light, temperature, pressure) and intracellular stimuli (e.g. calcium and G protein coupled receptors). More than 50 different TRP channels have been identified in organisms ranging from yeasts and protists to mammals. The experiments in this project will extend the study of TRP channels into one of the most primitive metazoans with a nervous system, the cnidarian Hydra. A characteristic of all the Cnidaria is the possession of stinging cells called cnidocytes, which in Hydra are responsible for prey capture, adhesion and locomotion. Although significant progress has been made in understanding development and regeneration in Hydra, the molecular mechanisms that control Hydra behaviors such as its feeding response and cnidocyte release are as of yet poorly understood. An examination of the Hydra genome revealed the presence of multiple candidate Hydra TRP channel genes. Whole mount in situ hybridization will be used to localize TRP channel expression to specific Hydra body regions. TRP channel function will be examined by testing known chemical TRP channel activators and inhibitors to determine if they affect Hydra feeding behavior or cnidocyte release, and if they affect the ability of Hydra to regenerate or to form buds during asexual reproduction. In addition, RNA interference will be used to silence the expression of specific Hydra TRP channels. The resulting TRP(-) hydra will then be tested in the functional assays to determine the effect of TRP channel gene silencing. The study of Hydra TRP channels could answer fundamental questions about the signal transduction systems involved in Hydra behaviors and development. A comparison of the primitive TRP channels in Hydra with the more recently evolved TRP channels of higher organisms will provide a useful mechanism for both structure-function analysis and for studying evolutionary relationships.


BROADER IMPACTS
Queensborough Community College (QCC) is an urban community college with a student population comprised of nearly equal numbers of Asians, Caucasians, Latinos and African Americans. Many of QCC's students come from low-income families, and are the first in their family to attend college. One of the goals of this project is to afford QCC undergraduates the opportunity to do research in a scientific laboratory. In the course of their research, students will learn Hydra culture methods, basic molecular biology techniques and DNA/protein sequence analysis. As the research in this project spans the spectrum from DNA sequence to development and behavior, students will learn how to make connections between events at the molecular level and those occurring at the level of the entire organism. In addition, since the TRP channel gene family is found in both very simple organisms such as yeast and in complex organisms like mammals, students will need to think in evolutionary terms when analyzing TRP channel function. Firsthand experience gained by working in a laboratory allows students to connect the theoretical concepts they learn in the classroom with real-world experiences. This will enhance their understanding of scientific concepts, and will give them the opportunity to apply their knowledge to their experiments in the laboratory. Student participation in research increases retention and graduation rates, a particularly important benefit at a community college like QCC, and undergraduates who are exposed to research early during their college careers are more likely to choose STEM majors and to remain in STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The regulation of behaviors by sensory stimuli is a complicated process, involving multiple interacting signal transduction pathways; this phenomenon is therefore more easily studied in a simple model system where behaviors are less complex and the organism is more easily manipulated.  The cnidarian Hydra is one of the simplest metazoans with differentiated cells and a nervous system, yet despite its simplicity Hydra nevertheless exhibits relatively complex behaviors.  These behaviors include a chemically stimulated stereotypical feeding response characterized by tentacle writhing and mouth opening, as well as cnidocyte (stinging cell) discharge, involving the integration of mechanical, chemical and photo stimuli.  Although significant progress has been made in understanding Hydra development and regeneration, the molecular mechanisms that control its behaviors are less well understood.

            Transient receptor potential (TRP) channels are a diverse superfamily of cation channels divided into seven families: TRPC, TRPV, TRPM, TRPML, TRPA, TRPN and PKD2.  More than 50 different TRP channels have been identified, in organisms ranging from protists to mammals; they can be activated by multiple types of stimuli (e.g. light, chemicals, touch, temperature) and act as polymodal cell sensors.  The nearly ubiquitous presence of TRP channels and their activation by a diverse variety of mechanisms suggest that these channels are also likely to function in Hydra.

            During the course of this project, two PKD2 TRP channels and an associated PKD1 gene were shown to exhibit highly localized patterns of expression around the hydra mouth and in hydra tentacles, implying functional roles in both cnidocyte discharge and mouth opening.  PKD2 and PKD1 genes belong to the polycystin superfamily.  Polycystins play significant roles in both extracellular and intracellular signaling in diverse processes such as development, sensing fluid flow, acid sensing in taste, regulation of stretch-activated channels and reproduction.  Like TRP channels, polycystins are expressed in simple unicellular protists as well as in complex organisms like mammals; they have been studied extensively in other model systems, such as C. elegans and D. melanogaster, but have not yet been examined in Hydra.  Since they are involved in both chemical and mechanosensitive signal transduction, polycystins are good candidates for roles in hydra behaviors that are activated by mechanical and/or chemical signals, such as cnidocyte discharge and the hydra feeding behavior.

            Behavioral experiments were used to further examine the role of polycystins in hydra behaviors.  Prey capture and mechanically-stimulated cnidocyte discharge are inhibited by the nonspecific PKD2 inhibitors neomycin and Gd3+.  In addition, both GSH (glutathione, a chemical activator of hydra feeding behavior) and triptolide (a PKD2 activator) stimulate cnidocyte discharge in both starved and satiated hydra.  These results suggest that a PKD2 channel is activated as part of a chemosensitive and/or mechanosensitive pathway during cnidocyte discharge.  GSH-stimulated mouth opening is also inhibited by Gd3+ and neomycin, but is not inhibited by verapamil (an inhibitor of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels).

            Results suggesting a possible role for calcium sensing receptors (CaSRs) in hydra behaviors were an unforeseen outcome of these experiments.  CaSRs belong to the G-protein coupled receptor superfamily; in vertebrates they respond to extracellular calcium to mediate processes such as Ca2+ homeostasis, chemotaxis, development and nutrient sensing.  Expression studies and behavioral experiments done as an extension of this project implicate these receptors in both cnidocyte discharge and hydra feeding behaviors.

            An examination of polycystin function in an organism like Hydra, which is highly diverged from vertebrates yet is phylogenetically considered to be a sister group of the Bilateria, may provide insights that cannot be gained by studying polycystins in other organisms.  In addition, a comparison of Hydra polycystin sequences to that of polycystins found in simple protists and in higher organisms will provide insights into the structural motifs that regulate the specificity and activity of these proteins and will also allow an examination of the evolution of this gene family.  The unforeseen results suggesting CaSR involvement in hydra behaviors provide an opportunity to develop a more complete understanding of how CaSRs evolved to play such important and varied roles in vertebrates, and could shed light on their possible interactions with members of the polycystin superfamily.
